summary.title: Computer Security
summary.description: This course focuses on security issues associated with computers and computer networks. The course starts by covering cryptographic topics such as symmetric and public key cryptography, digital signatures, secure hashes, random number generation, and message authentication codes. Network security topics are also covered including secure protocols (SSL/TLS, IPsec), network attack methods, network authentication protocols (Kerberos), and firewalls. Finally the course covers host security matters such as building secure software, auditing, and intrusion detection.

course-outcomes.outcome: Understand cryptographic technology well enough to recommend appropriate use of the technology and to deploy the technology both in the context of system administration and software development. The student should be able to appreciate the mathematical basis of encryption technology, however they need not be able to formally verify the strength or correctness of cryptographic algorithms.
Understand the details of at least one security protocol and be able to implement at least some aspects of it at either the administrative or software developmental capacity.
Understand the technical details of the SSL/TLS protocol. The students should be able to configure and use the protocol, as well as understand its limitations and advantages.
Describe how various network related attacks are performed as well as appropriate counter measures.
Understand the operation of the IPsec network layer protocol and its limitations and advantages.
Understand the purpose and limitations of firewalls.
Use appropriate methods to build secure software that avoid buffer overflows, use language security features, and interact with security support libraries (for example, PAM).
Understand the role of intrusion detection (at both the network and host levels), auditing, and similar technologies.

Understand various host based security technologies such as POSIX capabilities, ACLs, and DAC vs MAC. The students should be able to deal with these technologies, at least to a degree, in both an administrative and software development capacity.
Interact with other administrators to evaluate security risks, potential attacks, and appropriate countermeasures.

course-content.topic: Block encryption algorithms: DES and AES
Encryption modes and cryptographic random number generation
Network attack methods and countermeasures, firewalls
Building secure software (buffer overflows, language specific security features, interacting with security libraries, etc)
Host security mechanisms (capabilities, access control lists, discretionary access control, mandatory access control, etc)
